Prompt:
I need to do the following: select the last layer in the list of layers

The webapp has the following DOM Tree Structure (simplified + only human visible elements):
```
BODY
---DIV
---HEADER
------A (aria-label: "Field Maps Designer home page") > svg > path
------DIV
------NAV (aria-label: "Breadcrumb") > OL
------------LI > A > "Maps"
------------LI
---------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------LI (aria-label: "Map title: “solutio thymbra audax cohibeo”") > "solutio thymbra audax cohibeo"
------DIV > UL
------------LI > DIV > CALCITE-DROPDOWN
---------------------... > DIV > DIV
---------------------CALCITE-BUTTON
------------------------... > DIV > BUTTON
---------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------------------------SPAN
------------------------"local"
------------LI > A > "Resources"
------------DIV
------------LI > DIV > DIV > BUTTON
------------------------DIV > DIV > "GG"
------------------------SPAN > "Gussie"
---MAIN > DIV > DIV
------------CALCITE-ACTION-BAR
---------------... > CALCITE-ACTION-GROUP
---------------------... > DIV
---------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Collapse")
---------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------------------------DIV > "Collapse"
---------------CALCITE-ACTION-GROUP
------------------... > DIV
------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Overview")
------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------DIV > "Overview"
------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Forms")
------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------DIV > "Forms"
------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Geofences")
------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------DIV > "Geofences"
------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Offline")
------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------DIV > "Offline"
------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "App settings")
------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------DIV > "App settings"
------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Sharing")
------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------DIV > "Sharing"
---------------CALCITE-ACTION-MENU
------------------...
------------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Open")
------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------DIV > "Open"
---------------CALCITE-ACTION > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "What’s New (Indicator present)")
---------------------------DIV > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------------------DIV > "What’s New"
------------DIV
---------------HEADER > SPAN > "Forms"
---------------DIV
------------------INPUT
------------------BUTTON (aria-label: "Filter content") > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------DIV
------------------CALCITE-BLOCK
---------------------... > DIV > ARTICLE
------------------------------DIV > BUTTON
------------------------------------HEADER > DIV > H3 > "Layers"
------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path

---------------------------------------TD
---------------------------CALCITE-LABEL
------------------------------... > DIV
------------------------------"Port Shania"
---------------------------DIV
------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg
------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------CALCITE-BLOCK > ... > DIV > ARTICLE > DIV > BUTTON
------------------------------------HEADER > DIV > H3 > "Tables"
------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------CALCITE-BLOCK > ... > DIV > ARTICLE > DIV > BUTTON
------------------------------------HEADER > DIV > H3 > "Basemap"
------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------CALCITE-SPLIT-BUTTON > ... > DIV > DIV
---------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON
------------------------------... > DIV > BUTTON > SPAN
------------------------------"Add layers"
---------------------------DIV > DIV
---------------------------CALCITE-DROPDOWN
------------------------------... > DIV > DIV
------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Add existing layers or create new layers") > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------DIV > DIV
------------------svg > path
------------------DIV > "Canvas is empty"
------------------DIV > "Select an item in the Forms panel to configure its templates and form."
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The length of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, shorter means sibling of an ancestor.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the last layer in the list of layers"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example if they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or have its text exactly match with 'add'.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like so: page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
However, minimize the number of chained locators unless needed.
For example if there's only one element that would match getByText('add'), there is no need to chain locators before/after.

Use getByTestId if you can. This locates elements by data-testid attribute and is easier than chaining.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCITE-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use exact matching ({ exact: true }). Consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - If you want the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .nth(4).
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other locators; use chaining and/or other locators instead where possible.
 - we will add some modifications to your locator to guarantee finding the first visible matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.


Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the last layer in the list of layers 
Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM').last()"}
```
---

The agent performed some action on the page.

Before the action, the webapp has the following DOM Tree Structure (simplified + only human visible elements):
```

------------------------------------LI > DIV > DIV > DIV
------------------------------------------------DL > DT > "Switch"
------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON["aria-hidden:undefined->true","icon:undefined->toggle","calcite-hydrated:undefined->''"] > ... > svg > path
```

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'select the last layer in the list of layers' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
unknown 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 3: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{
    "Explanation": "The last layer in the list, 'Port Shania', is marked with the attribute 'selected:undefined->'''', indicating that it has been selected after the action. This suggests that the agent successfully performed the action of selecting the last layer.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The length of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, shorter means sibling of an ancestor.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example if they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or have its text exactly match with 'add'.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like so: page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
However, minimize the number of chained locators unless needed.
For example if there's only one element that would match getByText('add'), there is no need to chain locators before/after.

Use getByTestId if you can. This locates elements by data-testid attribute and is easier than chaining.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCITE-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use exact matching ({ exact: true }). Consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - If you want the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .nth(4).
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other locators; use chaining and/or other locators instead where possible.
 - we will add some modifications to your locator to guarantee finding the first visible matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.


Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar 
Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Tasks', { exact: true }).first()"}
```

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - content related to creating layouts is now visible 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 3: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{
    "Explanation": "After the action, the content related to creating layouts is now visible, indicating that the 'Tasks' tab was selected. The presence of the message 'Create layouts to configure actions' and the button 'New layout' supports this claim.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The length of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, shorter means sibling of an ancestor.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example if they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or have its text exactly match with 'add'.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like so: page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
However, minimize the number of chained locators unless needed.
For example if there's only one element that would match getByText('add'), there is no need to chain locators before/after.

Use getByTestId if you can. This locates elements by data-testid attribute and is easier than chaining.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCITE-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use exact matching ({ exact: true }). Consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - If you want the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .nth(4).
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other locators; use chaining and/or other locators instead where possible.
 - we will add some modifications to your locator to guarantee finding the first visible matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.


Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas 
Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('new-layout-btn')"}
```

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - a new "layout card" is added to the canvas
    - empty canvas instructions are removed. 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 3: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

---
Response:```json

    "Explanation": "The DOM after the action shows a new layout card with the title 'New layout' added to the canvas, and the previous empty canvas instructions have been removed. This indicates that the action to select the button labeled 'New Layout' was successfully performed.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The length of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, shorter means sibling of an ancestor.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "click the options menu button on the first layout card"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example if they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or have its text exactly match with 'add'.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like so: page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
However, minimize the number of chained locators unless needed.
For example if there's only one element that would match getByText('add'), there is no need to chain locators before/after.

Use getByTestId if you can. This locates elements by data-testid attribute and is easier than chaining.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCITE-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use exact matching ({ exact: true }). Consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - If you want the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .nth(4).
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other locators; use chaining and/or other locators instead where possible.
 - we will add some modifications to your locator to guarantee finding the first visible matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.


Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: click the options menu button on the first layout card 
Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('layouts-list').locator('FA-LAYOUT-CARD').first().locator('[data-testid=\"layout-actions-dropdown-trigger\"]')"}
```

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'click the options menu button on the first layout card' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - options to remove and duplicate for the first layout card are now visible 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 3: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

}
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The length of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, shorter means sibling of an ancestor.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "click the option to delete the first layout card"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example if they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or have its text exactly match with 'add'.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like so: page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
However, minimize the number of chained locators unless needed.
For example if there's only one element that would match getByText('add'), there is no need to chain locators before/after.

Use getByTestId if you can. This locates elements by data-testid attribute and is easier than chaining.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCITE-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use exact matching ({ exact: true }). Consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - If you want the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .nth(4).
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other locators; use chaining and/or other locators instead where possible.
 - we will add some modifications to your locator to guarantee finding the first visible matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.


Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: click the option to delete the first layout card 
Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('layout-actions-dropdown-trigger').first().click().then(() => page.getByTestId('layout-action-delete').first().click())"}
```

------------DIV > DIV
------------------svg > path
------------------DIV > "Canvas is empty"
------------------DIV > "Select an item in the Forms panel to configure its templates and form."
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The length of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, shorter means sibling of an ancestor.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the last layer in the list of layers"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example if they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or have its text exactly match with 'add'.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like so: page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
However, minimize the number of chained locators unless needed.
For example if there's only one element that would match getByText('add'), there is no need to chain locators before/after.

Use getByTestId if you can. This locates elements by data-testid attribute and is easier than chaining.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCITE-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use exact matching ({ exact: true }). Consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - If you want the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .nth(4).
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other locators; use chaining and/or other locators instead where possible.
 - we will add some modifications to your locator to guarantee finding the first visible matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.


Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the last layer in the list of layers 
Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM').last()"}
```
---

We expect to see the following side effects:
unknown 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 3: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

```
{

    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}

Prompt:
I need to do the following: select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar

The webapp has the following DOM Tree Structure (simplified + only human visible elements):
```
BODY
---DIV
---HEADER
------A (aria-label: "Field Maps Designer home page") > svg > path
------DIV
------NAV (aria-label: "Breadcrumb") > OL
------------LI > A > "Maps"
------------LI
---------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The length of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, shorter means sibling of an ancestor.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example if they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or have its text exactly match with 'add'.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like so: page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
However, minimize the number of chained locators unless needed.
For example if there's only one element that would match getByText('add'), there is no need to chain locators before/after.

Use getByTestId if you can. This locates elements by data-testid attribute and is easier than chaining.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCITE-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use exact matching ({ exact: true }). Consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - If you want the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .nth(4).
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other locators; use chaining and/or other locators instead where possible.
 - we will add some modifications to your locator to guarantee finding the first visible matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.


Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar 
Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Tasks', { exact: true }).first()"}
```
---

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - content related to creating layouts is now visible 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 3: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{
    "Explanation": "After the action, the content related to creating layouts is now visible, indicating that the 'Tasks' tab was selected. The presence of the 'Create layouts to configure actions' message and the 'New layout' button supports this claim.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The length of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, shorter means sibling of an ancestor.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example if they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or have its text exactly match with 'add'.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like so: page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
However, minimize the number of chained locators unless needed.
For example if there's only one element that would match getByText('add'), there is no need to chain locators before/after.

Use getByTestId if you can. This locates elements by data-testid attribute and is easier than chaining.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCITE-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use exact matching ({ exact: true }). Consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - If you want the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .nth(4).
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other locators; use chaining and/or other locators instead where possible.
 - we will add some modifications to your locator to guarantee finding the first visible matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.


Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas 
Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('new-layout-btn')"}
```

```

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - a new "layout card" is added to the canvas
    - empty canvas instructions are removed. 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 3: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{
    "Explanation": "The DOM after the interaction shows that a new layout card labeled 'New layout' has been added to the canvas, and the previous empty canvas instructions have been removed. This indicates that the action of selecting the button labeled 'New Layout' was successfully performed.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON (data-testid: "layout-actions-dropdown-trigger") > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Layout options menu") > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The length of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, shorter means sibling of an ancestor.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "click the options menu button on the first layout card"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example if they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or have its text exactly match with 'add'.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like so: page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
However, minimize the number of chained locators unless needed.
For example if there's only one element that would match getByText('add'), there is no need to chain locators before/after.

Use getByTestId if you can. This locates elements by data-testid attribute and is easier than chaining.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCITE-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use exact matching ({ exact: true }). Consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - If you want the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .nth(4).
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other locators; use chaining and/or other locators instead where possible.
 - we will add some modifications to your locator to guarantee finding the first visible matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.


Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: click the options menu button on the first layout card 
Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('layouts-list').locator('FA-LAYOUT-CARD').first().getByRole('button', { name: 'Layout options menu' })"}
```

------------------------------------------------------------LI > "All"
------------------------------------------------------------LI > "New layout"
------------------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-BUTTON (data-testid: "new-layout-btn")
------------------------------------------------... > DIV > BUTTON
---------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------------------------------------------------SPAN
------------------------------------------------"New layout"
---------------------------------------DIV > CALCITE-BUTTON
---------------------------------------------... > DIV > BUTTON
------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------------------------------SPAN
---------------------------------------------"Task filters"

---------------------------------------... > SECTION
---------------------------------------FACE-SORTABLE-LIST-ITEM
------------------------------------------... > DIV
------------------------------------------FA-LAYOUT-CARD > CALCITE-CARD
------------------------------------------------... > DIV > DIV > SECTION
------------------------------------------------------------HEADER > DIV
------------------------------------------------------------DIV
------------------------------------------------------------FOOTER
------------------------------------------------DIV
---------------------------------------------------SPAN (data-testid: "layout-title") > "New layout"
---------------------------------------------------CALCITE-DROPDOWN
------------------------------------------------------... > DIV > DIV
------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON (data-testid: "layout-actions-dropdown-trigger") > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Layout options menu") > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
```

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'click the options menu button on the first layout card' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - options to remove and duplicate for the first layout card are now visible 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 3: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The length of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, shorter means sibling of an ancestor.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "click the option to delete the first layout card"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example if they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or have its text exactly match with 'add'.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like so: page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
However, minimize the number of chained locators unless needed.
For example if there's only one element that would match getByText('add'), there is no need to chain locators before/after.

Use getByTestId if you can. This locates elements by data-testid attribute and is easier than chaining.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCITE-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use exact matching ({ exact: true }). Consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - If you want the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .nth(4).
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other locators; use chaining and/or other locators instead where possible.
 - we will add some modifications to your locator to guarantee finding the first visible matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.


Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: click the option to delete the first layout card 
Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('layout-actions-dropdown-trigger').first().locator('..').getByTestId('layout-action-delete')"}
```

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'click the option to delete the first layout card' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - the first layout card is deleted
    - the canvas is now empty 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 3: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{
    "Explanation": "The first layout card titled 'New layout' is no longer present in the DOM after the action, and the canvas now shows a message indicating it is empty, stating 'Create layouts to configure actions'. This indicates that the deletion of the layout card was successful.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

I need to do the following: select the last layer in the list of layers

The webapp has the following DOM Tree Structure (simplified + only human visible elements):

------------------DIV > "Canvas is empty"
------------------DIV > "Select an item in the Forms panel to configure its templates and form."
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The length of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, shorter means sibling of an ancestor.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the last layer in the list of layers"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example if they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or have its text exactly match with 'add'.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like so: page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
However, minimize the number of chained locators unless needed.
For example if there's only one element that would match getByText('add'), there is no need to chain locators before/after.

Use getByTestId if you can. This locates elements by data-testid attribute and is easier than chaining.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCITE-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use exact matching ({ exact: true }). Consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - If you want the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .nth(4).
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other locators; use chaining and/or other locators instead where possible.
 - we will add some modifications to your locator to guarantee finding the first visible matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.


Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the last layer in the list of layers 
Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM').last()"}
```
---

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'select the last layer in the list of layers' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
unknown 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 3: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

---

    "Explanation": "The last layer in the list, 'West Geo', is marked as selected in the updated DOM structure, indicating that the action to select the last layer was performed.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The length of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, shorter means sibling of an ancestor.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example if they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or have its text exactly match with 'add'.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like so: page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
However, minimize the number of chained locators unless needed.
For example if there's only one element that would match getByText('add'), there is no need to chain locators before/after.

Use getByTestId if you can. This locates elements by data-testid attribute and is easier than chaining.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCITE-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use exact matching ({ exact: true }). Consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - If you want the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .nth(4).
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other locators; use chaining and/or other locators instead where possible.
 - we will add some modifications to your locator to guarantee finding the first visible matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.


Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar 
Output:
---

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'select the 'Tasks' tab in the layer editor nav bar' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - content related to creating layouts is now visible 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 3: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

Output:
---
Response:```json
{
    "Explanation": "After the action, the content related to creating layouts is now visible, indicating that the 'Tasks' tab was selected. The presence of the 'Create layouts to configure actions' message and the 'New layout' button supports this claim.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

---------------------------------... > DIV > DIV
---------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON > ... > DIV > BUTTON > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
---------------------CALCITE-TAB
------------------------... > DIV > SECTION
------------------------DIV > FA-INDEX-VIEW (data-testid: "index-view") > FA-LAYOUTS-LIST (data-testid: "layouts-list") > FACE-CANVAS-EMPTY-STATE
------------------------------------... > DIV > svg > path
------------------------------------SPAN > "Create layouts to configure actions"
------------------------------------SPAN > "Configure the actions mobile workers use to complete tasks on their to-do list. Click + New layout to get started."
------------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON (data-testid: "new-layout-btn")
---------------------------------------... > DIV > BUTTON
------------------------------------------------CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
------------------------------------------------SPAN
---------------------------------------"New layout"
------------------------------------SPAN
---------------------------------------CALCITE-LINK
------------------------------------------... > DIV > A
------------------------------------------"Learn more"
---------------------------------------"about actions and layouts"
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The length of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, shorter means sibling of an ancestor.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example if they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or have its text exactly match with 'add'.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like so: page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
However, minimize the number of chained locators unless needed.
For example if there's only one element that would match getByText('add'), there is no need to chain locators before/after.

Use getByTestId if you can. This locates elements by data-testid attribute and is easier than chaining.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCITE-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use exact matching ({ exact: true }). Consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - If you want the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .nth(4).
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other locators; use chaining and/or other locators instead where possible.
 - we will add some modifications to your locator to guarantee finding the first visible matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.


Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas 
Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('new-layout-btn')"}
```
---

Follow the following steps:

Step 1: Identify the differences between the DOM before and after the interaction, if any.

Step 2: Use the following criteria along with any other information to determine if the step 'select the button labeled 'New Layout' in the canvas' was performed.
We expect to see the following side effects:
    - a new "layout card" is added to the canvas
    - empty canvas instructions are removed. 

Prove if the step was performed. Answer Yes/No and Briefly explain what evidence supports your claim.

Step 3: Score the agent's action between -1 and 1 in regards to the desired action. 
Reward the agent for correct responses and punish it for incorrect ones so it eventually learns how to accomplish the task.

Format your output like so:
```
{
    "Explanation": <brief evidence to support answer>
    "Answer": <'Yes' if step was performed, 'No' otherwise>
    "Score": <score between 0-1>
}
```

    "Explanation": "The new layout card titled 'New layout' is present in the canvas, and the previous empty canvas instructions have been removed, indicating that the action to select the button labeled 'New Layout' was successfully performed.",
    "Answer": "Yes",
    "Score": 1
}
```

------------------------------------------... > DIV
------------------------------------------FA-LAYOUT-CARD > CALCITE-CARD
------------------------------------------------... > DIV > DIV > SECTION
------------------------------------------------------------HEADER > DIV
------------------------------------------------------------DIV
------------------------------------------------------------FOOTER
------------------------------------------------DIV
---------------------------------------------------SPAN (data-testid: "layout-title") > "New layout"
---------------------------------------------------CALCITE-DROPDOWN
------------------------------------------------------... > DIV > DIV
------------------------------------------------------CALCITE-BUTTON (data-testid: "layout-actions-dropdown-trigger") > ... > DIV > BUTTON (aria-label: "Layout options menu") > CALCITE-ICON > ... > svg > path
```

In this DOM Tree Structure, '...' refers to a Shadow Root.
The length of the dashes ('---') conveys the relationship between an element and the element in the previous line; longer means child, same means sibling, shorter means sibling of an ancestor.

Your task is to:
```
Output a string representing an action that may accomplish the above task.

Each interaction should be provided in JSON format with the following structure:
{
  "action": "click|enter|type|tab|dragAndDrop|expect",
  "locatorCode": "code (to get the relevant element in Playwright)",
  "value": "value (only for type action)",
  "toLocatorCode": "code of locator for element to which first locator is being dragged to (only for dragAndDrop action)"
}
```

Follow the following steps as a guide:

Step 1: What part(s) of the DOM Tree above is relevant to the step "click the options menu button on the first layout card"?
 - consider a user might say something that isn't technically correct. For example if they say to 'click the add button' the element being referred to may not literally have 'button' tag, or have its text exactly match with 'add'.
 - You must infer what elements are relevant based on the semantics of the step and context provided by the DOM.

Step 2: What type of interaction do you want to perform on the above element? (e.g. click, type, etc.)

Step 3: Based on your answer to Step 1, identify the code that in Playwright that should be passed into "locatorCode" that can be used to find the relevant element via a locator.

Note you can chain locators like so: page.getByRole('...').locator('...').getByText('...').
However, minimize the number of chained locators unless needed.
For example if there's only one element that would match getByText('add'), there is no need to chain locators before/after.

Use getByTestId if you can. This locates elements by data-testid attribute and is easier than chaining.

The locators you can may are listed in the examples below.

Also consider these notes:
 - getByRole locates elements by its implicit role; however doesn't work for custom elements. ex: works for button, but not for CALCITE-LIST-ITEM
 - getByText matches elements by text. Use exact matching ({ exact: true }). Consider applying another locator before chaining getByText.
 - Use getByLabel to find alements by associated <label> or aria-label attribute
 - If you want the nth match using the nth= locator with a 0 based index; e.g. .nth(4).
 - Minimize usage of XPath / CSS selectors as they cannot go through a Shadow DOM and are more brittle than other locators; use chaining and/or other locators instead where possible.
 - we will add some modifications to your locator to guarantee finding the first visible matching element.
 
We will evaluate the code passed into "locatorCode" in Playwright. 
You are looking at test data so try not to refer to the test data text in your selectors.

Step 4: Verify your code is well-formed Playwright code as described above. If there are errors, do your best to fix them. Try to use a different locator.


Step 5: Output the interaction in the JSON format described earlier.
Your output should be in JSON format. No trailing commas.

Examples:
```
// getByRole
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByRole('button', { name: submit })"}
// getByLabel
{"action": “enter”, "locatorCode": "page.getByLabel('Password’)”}
// getByText
{"action": “tab”, "locatorCode": "page.getByText('Welcome, John'), { exact: true }”}
// getByTestID
{"action": “type”, "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('directions’)”, “value”:”180 New York Street”}
// XPath:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('[data-test-interactions]');"}
// CSS:
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM:nth-child(4)')"}
```

Recall, I need to: click the options menu button on the first layout card 
Output:
---
Response:```json
{"action": "click", "locatorCode": "page.getByTestId('layouts-list').locator('CALCITE-LIST-ITEM').first().locator('[data-testid=\"layout-actions-dropdown-trigger\"]')"}
```
---
